Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery kylix; interior: glazed black (only traces remaining) with traces of tondo with band at its edge; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of animal procession to left (body, wing with added red dabs and feet of bird or siren); below, three narrow and one wide black band above further glazed area.
Curator's comments: The sherd comes from an open vessel, probably a kylix (not a round aryballos as stated by Venit and Möller). The sherd is facing the wrong direction in Venit. For the shape and the winged creature, compare the cup attributed to the Medallion Painter, Boston 12.422 (Amyx 1988, 195, pl. 76; Boardman 1998, 197, figs 393,1,2). The sherd probably belongs with British Museum 1924,1201.1191.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 67, no. A52)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 221, no. 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.096) (Phase 1)
